Comment: Larsen scored some fine victories with this opening named Nimzowitsch-Larsen attack.
White allows Black to occupy the centre which is hyper-modern opening.
White starts his attack against Black's centre.

White saddles Black with doubled pawns on c-file. Now the e-pawn will be attacked. A typical hyper modern opening. White exchanged his developed knight and is behind in development.

9. d4 would have captured the centre for White.
Black castles on the queen side to avoid an attack by the long range White bishop on b2.
White's opening strategy seems to be clear. His bishop on b2 is being supported by a strong pawn chain. Black cannot capture the f-pawn by en passant as the bishop is on f4.
Black attacks the f2 square with his knight. Looks like a typical amateur play but Spassky was the World champion in 1970.
Black starts his attack.

White tries to drive away the pesky knight.
!! Black offers the knight. Spassky has devised a brilliant maneuvre to take advantage of the White king in the centre.
Larsen, an aggressive player himself, spent 45 minutes before accepting the knight and probably could not see the maneuver planned by Spassky.
!!! This is the move which won the brilliancy prize. A second piece being offered. Can we see any attack after this?

A tiny pawn is sufficient to bring White's game down.
A tiny pawn is sufficient to bring White's game down.
Larsen hopes for gxf1 but Spassky did not sac 2 pieces for nothing. 16. Rg1 may have been better but Larsen must have lost his cool by Spassky's audacious sacrifices.

Larsen resigns as White is mated in 3 moves. Can we see the mate at least now? It is amazing that Larsen, a top flight grandmaster playing on top board, for World team should have collapsed in his own opening. So it is Ok if we lose our games in similar fashion, eh?
